attributes.category: Health Care Professional or Association - HC001
attributes.comment:
This comment is in response to the Request for Information: National Directory of Healthcare Providers & Services, file code CMS-005-NC.

A directory of healthcare providers and services is already in existence. It is called the National Provider Identifier (NPI). See the following web address.

https://npiregistry.cms.hhs.gov/search

It is a requirement to have a valid and active NPI number for most operations of patient treatment, terms for any insurance reimbursement, and the majority of the time is required when a patient must be referred other services outside of primary care scope of practice.

When it comes time for medical professionals to update their current practicing locations or names on this registry due to changing jobs or getting married, this seems to create a bunch of emotional break downs and apparent psychological trauma. This is something I get screamed at about routinely when I need to make the dreaded call to a referring provider alerting them that their NPI Registry hasn't been updated since 2011 and this is why their address isn't matching up with where they are currently practicing; because said provider has moved several times in the past 11 years but hasn't updated their NPI registry. This means it is really difficult to locate said medical provider if they aren't on a current website that is managed by someone who understands the value of good search engine optimization. (I’m totally aware that this paragraph is a ton of BLAH BLAH BLAH. Welcome to my personal h3ll).

Seeing as how most medical practices are struggling to obtain any hired help, whether it be qualified professions to administrative staff, adding yet another 'regulatory' or 'compliance' burden to the repertoire is just one more road block that will interrupt patient treatment and work flow.

How is this going to improve an overburdened work force's ability to spend more time taking care of their patients? Caring for our fellow humans in their vulnerable time of need is what the majority of us were ‘called’ to do, from doctors, care extenders, administrative front office people, and everyone in between. I don't think anyone's calling is to keep track of another redundant platform, policy, or potential compliance violation fodder.

If it is the intend to create another national registry of provider info, it is great to start with asking for input. Thank you for putting this out for public comment and input. I hope that this leads to repairs of existing systems or to remove what isn't working in favor of something that will be more effective, efficient and user friendly. Thank you.
